Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Initial Appearance as to Raymond E. Hiraldo-Figueroa(4), Juan C. Ortega-Rivera(5), Elvin O. Ortiz-Correa(9), William Crespo-Rivera(10), Alejandro Feliciano-Andino(12), Luis E. Fuentes-Walker(13) held on 3/19/2013. Present: AUSA Alberto Lopez and USPTO Carolina Aparicio. Defendants were provided with copy of the Indictment and advised as to the charges and their rights. After reviewing the CJA-23 forms filled by defendants, the Court deemed it appropriate to appoint counsel. Defendant #4 will be represented by FPD all other defendants will be represented by CJA counsel. Defendants ordered temporarily detained pending hearings. Arraignment/Detention set for 3/22/2013 at 1:30 PM in Courtroom 10 before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez. (amr) (Entered: 03/20/2013)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Initial Appearance / Detention Hearings as to Raul Alvarez-Hernandez held on 3/19/2013. Present: AUSA Alberto Lopez and USPTO Carolina Aparicio. Defendant was provided with copy of the Indictment and advised as to the charges and his rights. After reviewing the CJA-23 form filled by defendant, the Court deemed it appropriate to appoint counsel. Defendant will be represented by CJA counsel. As to Detention, the Court imposed bail in the amount of $5,000.00 unsecured, employment, plus all other standard conditions of release apply. Government had no objection to bail, but requested that defendant reside outside area mentioned in the indictment. After a brief inquired by the Court, the possibility of alternate residence is not probable at this time. Government can reopen issue at arraignment hearing. Arraignment set for 4/1/2013 at 9:15 AM in Courtroom 10 before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez. (amr) (Entered: 03/20/2013)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Initial Appearance / Detention Hearings as to Diana Colon held on 3/19/2013. Defendant was provided with copy of the Indictment and advised as to the charges and her rights. After reviewing the CJA-23 form filled by defendant, the Court deemed it appropriate to appoint counsel. Defendant will be represented by CJA counsel. As to Detention, the Court imposed bail in the amount of $5,000.00 unsecured, including education; mental evaluation and/or treatment as deemed necessary, plus all other standard conditions of release apply. Government had no objection to bail, but requested that defendant reside outside area mentioned in the indictment. After a brief inquired by the Court, the possibility of alternate residence is not probable at this time. Government can reopen issue at arraignment hearing. Arraignment set for 4/1/2013 at 9:15 AM in Courtroom 10 before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez. (amr) (Entered: 03/20/2013)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Arraignment/Detention as to Alexis Parrilla-Echevarria (23) Count 1,2-4 held on 3/22/2013. Present: AUSA Alberto Lopez, Atty. Juan Milanes. Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment and entered a plea of not guilty as to all counts. The Government has 7 days to produce discovery and the defense has 14 days thereafter to file motions. Case is referred to Judge Garcia-Gregory for trial setting. As to detention, defense counsel had no evidence to rebut the presumption, but reserved the right to reopen the hearing. The Court ordered defendant detained on the basis of risk of flight and danger to the community. (Court Reporter FTR.)Hearing set for 01:30.Hearing held at 01:52.Hearing ended at 01:55.Interpreter Mary Jo Smith. (ft) (Entered: 04/03/2013)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Arraignment/Detention as to Juan C. Ortega-Rivera (5) Count 1,2-4,5 held on 3/22/2013. Present: AUSA Alberto Lopez, Atty. Jose Gaztambide. Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment and entered a plea of not guilty as to all counts. The Government has 7 days to produce discovery and the defense has 14 days thereafter to file motions. Case is referred to Judge Garcia-Gregory for trial setting. As to detention, defense counsel proffered that defendant's mother is willing to serve as third party custodian. The government requested detention. The Court ordered defendant detained on the basis of risk of flight and danger to the community. (Court Reporter FTR.)Hearing set for 01:30.Hearing held at 01:56.Hearing ended at 02:01.Interpreter Mary Jo Smith. (ft) Modified on 4/3/2013 to correct filing date. (ft). (Entered: 04/03/2013)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Arraignment/Detention as to Luis E. Fuentes-Walker (13) Count 1,2-4 held on 3/22/2013. Present: AUSA Alberto Lopez, Atty. Juan Hernandez. Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment and entered a plea of not guilty as to all counts. The Government has 7 days to produce discovery and the defense has 14 days thereafter to file motions. Case is referred to Judge Garcia-Gregory for trial setting. As to detention,  defense counsel disagreed with the recommendations of the pretrial report and argued in favor of bail. The government had no objection that defendant be released, but recommended to place the defendant with an EMD. The Court imposed bail in the amount of $3,000.00 of which $1,500.00 will be cash or secured and $1,500.00 unsecured, father or mother to be qualified as third party custodian, employment, plus all other standard conditions of release. (Court Reporter FTR.)Hearing set for 01:30.Hearing held at 02:02.Hearing ended at 02:09 Interpreter Mary Jo Smith. (ft) (Entered: 04/03/2013)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez- Rive:Initial Appearance as to Angel Canales-Villalongo, Jackeline Rentas-De-Jesus, Liza Andino, Nathanael Ramos-Santos held on 4/2/2013. Present were AUSA Teresa Zapata and AFPD Victor Gonzalez-Bothwell. Defendants appeared in this district after being arrested in Pennsylvania and released on bond, with strict instructions to appear today in PR. They were provided with copies of the indictment and advised as to the charges and their rights. The FPD's Office was appointed to represent them in today's proceedings, after which CJA counsels will be appointed to represent each of these defendants. Arraignment/Detention as to Angel Canales-Villalongo (17) Count 1,2-4 and Jackeline Rentas-De-Jesus (22) Count 1,2-4 and Liza Andino (28) Count 1,2-4 and Nathanael Ramos-Santos (30) Count 1,2-4 held on 4/2/2013. All four defendants were found competent at this time to understand the proceedings. They waived the reading of the indictment and entered a plea of not guilty as to all counts with which they are charged. The parties will have 7 days for discovery and 14 days thereafter to file any motions. Case is referred to Judge Garcia for scheduling. As to bail, the Court adopted the same conditions imposed in the District of Pennsylvania: $50,000.00 unsecured, plus all other standard conditions of release. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez- Rive:Arraignment/Bail as to Jose A. Rivera-Ayala (2) Count 1,2-4,5 held on 7/9/2013. Present were AUSA Marshal Morgan and Mr. Jorge Vega-Pacheco. Dft is present and under custody. Defendant was found competent at this time to understand the proceedings. He waived the reading of the Indictment and entered a plea of not guilty as to all counts. The parties will have 7 days for discovery and 14 days thereafter to file any motions. Case is referred to Judge Garcia for scheduling. Mr. Vega-Pacheco stated that at this time they had nothing to offer since defendant had a detained in the State of Pennsylvania. The Court ordered defendant detained without bail. Order to issue. Mr. Vega Pacheco requested that if defendant was to be moved outside of Puerto Rico, that it be done after the 15th of this month as his family was coming to Puerto Rico to see him. The Court ordered that copy of the minutes be provided to the USM so that this be taken into consideration. Present were AUSA Alberto Lopez and Mr. Ernesto Hernandez. Dft was present and on bond. Waiver of JT and consent to proceed before a U. S. Magistrate Judge was filed and accepted in open court. The defendant is found competent to understand the proceedings. He is advised of the maximum penalties he's facing, his constitutional rights, consequences of waiving said rights and the applicable statutory guidelines. After hearing the parties, the Magistrate Judge will issue a Report and Recommendation to Judge Garcia so that the guilty plea as to count One (1) of the Indictment be accepted. The Court orders the preparation of the Pre-Sentence Report. Sentencing Hearing to be set by Judge Garcia. Defendant to remain under same conditions of release. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Change of Plea Hearing as to Angel Canales-Villalongo was called but not held on 3/10/2014. AUSA Alberto Lopez was present. Counsel Hector Deliz and defendant were not present in court. Counsel filed a third motion ECF 577 , being exactly the same as the first two motions with the same allegations, ECF 413 and 523 , except for the first paragraph. At the last hearing, the Court found that it was not acceptable to file a motion to continue, not having it ruled either by the Judge or Magistrate Judge, and not show up. The Government had extended the plea offer until 2/28/2014. The Court had granted defense counsels last motion to continue. The hearing was rescheduled for today and  counsel does the same exact thing. This is the third time that counsel file a motion on short notice and not show up, it is unacceptable. The Government will get in touch with counsel Deliz. The Court has issued an ordered to show cause why sanctions should not be imposed and why the case should not be sent for a trial setting. ORDER as to Elvin O. Ortiz-Correa (9): The change of plea hearing as to defendant Elvin O. Ortiz-Correa has been scheduled four times. ECF Nos. 520, 559, 594, 631. Two status conferences have been held in an attempt to address the particular circumstances of the defendant. ECF Nos. 663, 765. A previous order detailing defendant's failure to comply with deadlines has been issued. ECF Nos. 719. Now, defendant has once again failed to comply with a deadline set by the court, even after the court granted the extension requested. ECF Nos. 765, 807, 808. Evidently, the change of plea motion (ECF No. 515) was prematurely filed. The defendant shall be deemed to be among those that wish to exercise their right to a trial by jury. If defendant wishes to have a change of plea hearing, he shall file a new motion requesting a change of plea hearing with the proposed plea agreement signed by the parties tendered as an exhibit. If such motion is filed, the undersigned will proceed to schedule a change of plea hearing. The government is granted until August 25, 2014, to respond to the pro se motions that have been filed. See ECF Nos. 778 and 779. Signed by US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez on 8/20/14.(Lopez, Marcos) (Entered: 08/20/2014)

Defendant was present, on bond and assisted by a certified court interpreter. No objections to the PSI Report. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of the defense. Defendant's allocution heard. Sentence imposed as to Count(s) 1, Impr Term: Time Already Served Under Custody. SRT: 3 years. SMA: $100.00. Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory:Sentencing held on 2/25/2019 for Yanibal Ortiz-Arroyo (25). Present were AUSA Nadia Pineda, Defense Counsel Saul Roman-Santiago and USPO Wilmarisa Martinez. The Defendant was present in court, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Parties heard. Defendants allocution heard. Defendant was sentence to 60 months of imprisonment (time served to be credited); SRT of 8 years. SMA of $100.00. The defendant was advised of his right to appeal. Government requested that remaining count(s) be dismissed. Request granted. Recommendation to the BOP: 1. That defendant be designated to FMC Rochester, MN, where he may be treated for his medical condition. 2. That he be provided mental health treatment. 3. That he be provided with the 500 hours drug treatment. 4. That defendant be enrolled in an educational/vocational rehabilitation training program. (Court Reporter Joe Reynosa.)Hearing set for 03:00.Hearing held at 03:36.Hearing ended at 03:53.Interpreter Olga Uribe. (su) (Entered: 02/25/2019)

JUDGMENT as to Yanibal Ortiz-Arroyo (25), Count(s) 1, Imprisonment for a term of 60 months (time served to be credited). SRT of 8 years. SMA of $100.00; Count(s) 2-4, Dismissed. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 2/25/2019.(su) (Entered: 02/25/2019)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Initial Appearance re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Jose R. Rodriguez-Rivera (24)  held on 3/17/2020. AUSA Corinne Cordero and AFPD Javier Cuyar were present. Defendant was under custody, present in court and assisted by the certified court interpreter. A copy of ECF No. 1275 was provided to the defendant. He was advised of the SRT violations and his right to a preliminary hearing to determine whether his supervised release conditions have been violated or not. The Court deemed it appropriate to appoint counsel. The Federal Public Defender was appointed to represent the defendant. Defense counsel argued for conditions of release. The government did not oppose. The Court modified defendant's conditions of supervised release by adding electronic monitoring; home detention; and defendant is allowed to work from 9:00 am to 7:00 pm. The USPO shall confirm if a landline is necessary for the electronic monitoring. A Preliminary Revocation Hearing is set for 3/20/2020 at 10:30 AM in Courtroom 10 before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez. If the government intends to call a witness that is not fluent in the English language, failure of the government to timely retain the services of an interpreter may result in the imposition of sanctions. (Court Reporter DCR / Courtroom 10.) Hearing held at 10:37. Hearing ended at 10:50. Interpreter Virginia Santamaria. (jjr) (Entered: 03/17/2020)

ORDER denying without prejudice 1291 Motion Requesting Order as to Miguel A. Canales-Villalongo (1); noted 1299 Motion in Compliance as to Miguel A. Canales- Villalongo (1). Defendant has failed to establish that compassionate release is warranted pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Specifically, Defendant has failed to establish: (1) exhaustion of administrative remedies; (2) extraordinary and compelling reasons justifying a reduction in sentence; (3) that he does not pose a danger to the community; and (4) that a sentence reduction is consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements issued by the Sentencing Commission. Even assuming, without deciding, that the Court may excuse the failure to exhaust administrative remedies, Defendant's motion lacks specific information or evidence supporting the allegations of preexisting health conditions that would increase for Defendant the risks posed by COVID-19 infection beyond the risks posed to the general population. See United States v. Raia, 954 F.3d 594, 597 (3d Cir. 2020) ("We do not mean to minimize the risks that COVID-19 poses in the federal prison system... But the mere existence of COVID-19 in society and the possibility that it may spread to a particular prison alone cannot independently justify compassionate release, especially considering BOP's statutory role, and its extensive and professional efforts to curtail the virus's spread."); United States v. Eberhart, 2020 WL 1450745, at *2 (N.D. Cal. Mar. 25, 2020) ("[A] reduction of sentence due solely to concerns about the spread of COVID-19 is not consistent with the applicable policy statement of the Sentencing Commission as required by § 3582(c) (1)(A)."). Defendant may refile the present motion provided he submits evidence to satisfy the requirements of 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Finally, Defendant has failed to show that this Court has jurisdiction over his request for home confinement, considering that the BOP is solely responsible for determining an inmate's place of incarceration. See 18 U.S.C. § 3621(b). Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 6/19/2020. (MQ) (Entered: 06/19/2020)

ORDER denying 1312 Motion Requesting Order as to Jose A. Rivera-Ayala (2); noted 1317 Motion in Compliance as to Jose A. Rivera-Ayala (2); granting 1318 Motion for Extension of Time as to Jose A. Rivera-Ayala (2). Defendant's sentence was correctly calculated. Defendant received a reduction in the base offense level for Count 1 pursuant to Amendment 782, from 26 to 24, reducing the total offense level from 28 to 26 and yielding a guideline imprisonment range of 63-78 months. Defendant was then sentenced to 70 months for Count 1. Moreover, while the Supreme Court recently held that § 924(c)(3)(B) is unconstitutionally vague, United States v. Davis, 139 S.Ct. 2319, 2336 (2019), Defendant's conviction does not rely on this crime of violence definition. Nor does Defendant's conviction involve the "stacking" of multiple 924(c) offenses. Finally, Defendant is ineligible for relief under the First Step Act. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 11/17/2020. (MQ) (Entered: 11/17/2020)

Statement in support of 1331 MOTION for Compassionate Release as to Miguel A. Canales-Villalongo (1) filed by Suleimi Garay-Tiburcio. (Attachments: # 1 Envelope) (gav) (Entered: 02/16/2021)

ORDER denying without prejudice 1336 Motion for Compassionate Release - 18 U.S.C. Section 3582(c)(1)(A) as to Raymond E. Hiraldo-Figueroa (4); noted 1343 Motion in Compliance as to Raymond E. Hiraldo-Figueroa (4). Defendant has failed to meet his burden of establishing that compassionate release is warranted pursuant to 18 U.S.C. § 3582(c)(1)(A). Specifically, Defendant has failed to establish: (1) exhaustion of administrative remedies; (2) extraordinary and compelling reasons justifying a reduction in sentence; (3) that he does not pose a danger to the community; and (4) that a sentence reduction is consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements issued by the Sentencing Commission. Even if the Court were to excuse the failure to exhaust administrative remedies, Defendant's motion lacks specific information and evidence supporting the allegations of preexisting health conditions that would increase for Defendant the risks posed by COVID-19 infection beyond the risks posed to the general population. See United States v. Raia, 954 F.3d 594, 597 (3d Cir. 2020) ("We do not mean to minimize the risks that COVID-19 poses in the federal prison system... But the mere existence of COVID-19 in society and the possibility that it may spread to a particular prison alone cannot independently justify compassionate release, especially considering BOP's statutory role, and its extensive and professional efforts to curtail the  virus's spread."). While Defendant claims to suffer from hyperlipidemia, this condition is not included in the CDC's list of underlying medical conditions that may increase the risk of severe illness from COVID-19. Defendant has similarly failed to show that he does not pose a danger to the community, considering the crimes of conviction, his leadership role in the offense, and his disciplinary infractions while imprisoned (including assault without serious injury, possession of a dangerous weapon, and fighting with another inmate); or that a sentence reduction would be consistent with 18 U.S.C. § 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements. For these reasons, Defendant's Motion is hereby DENIED without prejudice. Defendant may refile the present motion provided he submits evidence to satisfy the requirements of 18 U.S.C. § 3582(c)(1)(A). Finally, Defendant has failed to show that this Court has jurisdiction over any request for home confinement, considering that the BOP is solely responsible for determining an inmates place of incarceration. See 18 U.S.C. § 3621(b). Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 2/16/2021. (MQ) (Entered: 02/16/2021)

ORDER as to Miguel A. Canales-Villalongo (1) denying with prejudice 1335 Motion for Reconsideration. This is Defendant's fourth motion requesting a reduction of sentence pursuant to 18 U.S.C. § 3582, yet it still suffers from the same deficiencies previously identified by the Court. See Docket Nos. 1300; 1302; 1327. Specifically, Defendant has failed to establish: (1) exhaustion of administrative remedies; (2) extraordinary and compelling reasons justifying a reduction in sentence; (3) that he does not pose a danger to the community; and (4) that a sentence reduction is consistent with 18 U.S.C. § 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements issued by the Sentencing Commission. Even though Defendant is overweight and suffers from asthma, FCI Allenwood Low seems to be taking adequate steps to prevent outbreaks considering that it has maintained low numbers of active cases and, currently, only has 1 inmate with COVID-19. Thus, Defendant has not shown extraordinary and compelling circumstances. Moreover, Defendant has not shown that he does not pose a danger to others, considering his drug and firearm convictions, leadership role in the crimes charged, and prior conviction for aggravated battery. Considering that Defendant has had 4 opportunities to request relief under § 3582 to no avail, the request is hereby DENIED WITH PREJUDICE. Defendant may not refile this petition. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 2/16/2021. (MQ) (Entered: 02/16/2021)

ORDER denying without prejudice 1344 Motion for Compassionate Release - 18 U.S.C. Section 3582(c)(1)(A) as to Jorge Quinonez-Osorio (6); noted 1353 Motion in Compliance as to Jorge Quinonez-Osorio (6). Defendant has failed to meet his burden of establishing that compassionate release is warranted pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1) (A). Specifically, Defendant has failed to establish: (1) exhaustion of administrative remedies; (2) extraordinary and compelling reasons justifying a reduction in sentence; (3) that he does not pose a danger to the community; and (4) that a sentence reduction is consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements issued by the Sentencing Commission. Even if the Court were to excuse the failure to exhaust administrative remedies, Defendant's motion lacks specific allegations of preexisting health conditions, much less evidence to that effect, that would increase for Defendant the risks posed by COVID-19 infection beyond the risks posed to the general population. See United States v. Raia, 954 F.3d 594, 597 (3d Cir. 2020) ("We do not mean to minimize the risks that COVID-19 poses in the federal prison system... But the mere existence of COVID-19 in society and the possibility that it may spread to a particular prison alone cannot independently justify compassionate release, especially considering BOP's statutory role, and its extensive and professional efforts to curtail the virus's spread."). Defendant has similarly failed to show that he does not pose a danger to the community, considering the crimes of conviction and his leadership role in the offense; or that a sentence reduction would be consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements. For these reasons, Defendant's Motion is hereby DENIED without prejudice. Defendant may refile the present motion provided he submits evidence to satisfy the requirements of 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1 (A). ORDER denying without prejudice 1368 Motion for Compassionate Release - 18 U.S.C. Section 3582(c)(1)(A) as to Yanibal Ortiz-Arroyo (25); noted 1374 Motion in Compliance as to Yanibal Ortiz-Arroyo (25). Defendant has failed to meet his burden of establishing that a sentence reduction is warranted pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Specifically, Defendant has failed to establish: (1) extraordinary and compelling reasons justifying a reduction in sentence; (2) that he does not pose a danger to the community; and (3) that a sentence reduction is consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements issued by the Sentencing Commission. Defendant has submitted evidence that he is overweight and may suffer from an immunocompromised state from  immune weakening medicines, which according to the CDC might increase for Defendant the risks posed by COVID-19 infection beyond the risks posed to the general population. See United States v. Raia, 954 F.3d 594, 597 (3d Cir. 2020) ("We do not mean to minimize the risks that COVID-19 poses in the federal prison system... But the mere existence of COVID-19 in society and the possibility that it may spread to a particular prison alone cannot independently justify compassionate release, especially considering BOP's statutory role, and its extensive and professional efforts to curtail the virus's spread."). This, coupled with the high number of inmates who have contracted COVID-19 at FCI Fort Dix, might constitute extraordinary and compelling circumstances. However, Defendant has already recovered from COVID-19. He has also failed to show that he does not pose a danger to the community, considering the crime of conviction, his prior criminal history, and his disciplinary infractions while imprisoned; or that a sentence reduction would be consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements. For these reasons, Defendant's Motion is hereby DENIED without prejudice. Defendant may refile the present motion provided he submits evidence to satisfy the requirements of 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Finally, Defendant has failed to show that this Court has jurisdiction over any request for home confinement, considering that the BOP is solely responsible for determining an inmates place of incarceration. See 18 U.S.C. § 3621(b). Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 3/24/2021. (MQ) (Entered: 03/24/2021)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory:Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Victor J. Calderon-Zayas (14) held via VTC on 5/17/2021. Present were AUSA Juan Reyes, AFPD Victor Gonzalez and USPO Joseline Perez. Defendant was ON BOND, present in Court via VTC and assisted by a certified court interpreter. The defendant waived his right to appear physically for this proceeding and agreed to proceed with the via VTC due to the COVID-19 emergency and pursuant to CARES Act, § 15002(b)(1). Defendant does not contest the alleged violations. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of the defense. Defendant's allocution heard. After hearing the parties, the Court revokes the previously imposed SRT and sentenced defendant to 4 hours in US Probation Office to meet with USPO Joseline Perez on Thursday May 20, 2021 from 8:30 AM to 12:30 PM, and a SRT of 1 year. Thereafter, AUSA Reyes requested reconsideration as to the SRT. Parties heard. The Court granted Oral Motion for Reconsideration and sentence defendant to 4 years of SRT. Defendant was advised of his right to appeal (Court Reporter Rachelle Robinson.)Hearing set for 02:30.Hearing held at 02:59.Hearing ended at 03:33.Interpreter Carlos Ravelo. (su) (Entered: 05/18/2021)
